did.abstract: Robert Heinich was a professor in the School of Education at Indiana University from 1969 to 1990. During his time at IU, he served as the chair of the Instructional Systems Technology Program. Heinich also served for several years as editor of the Journal of Educational Computing Research. This collection largely contains copies of scholarly articles written by Heinich. Also included in the collection are interviews, biographical information, and Heinich's dissertation.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research. Advance notice is required.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Robert Heinich was born on May 31, 1923 in Ridgewood, New York. He first attended Copper Union until World War II interrupted his studies and he joined the Army Air Corps in 1943. He left the Air Corps in 1946 and enrolled at Colorado State College (now the University of Northern Colorado). He earned both his BA (1948) and MA (1949) from Colorado State. Beginning in 1949 he worked as the Audio-Visual Director for the Colorado Public Schools. In 1962, he decided to pursue his Ph.D. at the University of Southern California. He worked as an Assistant Professor in the School of Education at USC, and completed his doctorate in 1967. His dissertation won the Dissertation of the Year Award from the USC School of Education. After graduating, he worked for two years as the director of the Educational Services Division at Doubleday and Co.

Heinich joined the faculty at Indiana University as a Professor of Education in the Department of Instructional Systems Technology, School of Education. From 1979 to 1984 Heinich served as chair of the Instructional Systems Technology program. He is the co-author of Instructional Media and the New Technologies of Instruction (1982), a highly regarded book in the field of educational technology. The book won two awards, a "DESI" award (Design Institute of America) and a Communication of the Year Award from the National Society for Performance and Instruction.

In 1986, he served as the director of the Hangzhou University (China)/Indiana University Exchange Program. Additionally, he spent two months on a lecture tour in China in 1988. The tour went to several universities, including Hunan Normal University and Shanghai International Studies University.

Outside of his work at IU, Heinich served as co-editor, senior consulting editor, contributing editor, and on editorial boards for a variety of journals including Educational Technology, Educational Communication and Technology, and the Journal of Educational Computing Research. In 1975 he was given the Special Service award from the AECT (Association of Educational Communications and Technology), and in 1981, he was given the Distinguished Service Award by the same organization. Heinich also earned other awards for his work.
Professor Heinich was named Professor Emeritus of Education and retired from IU in May of 1990.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized into one series: Subject files. The collection was organized by Heinich and his colleague in the School of Education, Michael Molenda.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The collection contains only one series. Included are a biographical sketches, interviews, correspondence with associates, scholarly articles written by Heinich, a key note address given by Heinich, a t-shirt made after 1968 which features a famous statement by Heinich, "Technology makes instruction visible," and his doctoral dissertation Technology and the Management of Instruction..

The correspondence is from Charles F. Hoban Jr., Francis W. Noel, and Gerald M Torkelson and concerns professional matters of education. The Hoban correspondence largely deals with articles written by Hoban for a journal for which Heinich served as editor. The Noel correspondence concerns Noel's evaluations of others in the educational technology field. The Torkelson correspondence revolves around a special 25th anniversary issue of AV Communication
